description: Borrowed from Late Latin, Medieval Latin decimalis, from Latin decimus, from decem (“ten”) + adjective suffix -alis.

entries.meaning: (arithmetic, computing) Concerning numbers expressed in decimal or mathematical calculations performed using decimal.
(countable) A number expressed in the base-ten system, (particularly) a fractional numeral written in this system.

examples: Pi has a value of 3.142, to three decimals.

verbs.description: decimal (third-person singular simple present decimals, present participle decimaling or decimalling, simple past and past participle decimaled or decimalled)

entries.meaning: To represent with numbers after a decimal point.
examples: Single- decimaled entries, often originating in Whiting (Wh) or Wilson (OW; see p. 23, fn.3), are from SPL. To save space, examples cited in SPL are normally not repeated (examples therefore begin with "Add:"). Double- decimaled entries, again often based on Wh or OW, are "new."
